headline: Opinion | RFK Jr. proves the fallacy of ‘doing your own research’ - The Washington Post
context: Back in the early 1990s, pre-mass internet, when being a conspiracy theorist was really more of a regional gig than a national one, an Arizona radio host named Milton William Cooper propagated a loose consortium of theories via shortwave broadcast on topics including but not limited to: the Kennedy assassination, the U.S. government, Waco, AIDS, the IRS, the Illuminati — and of course, UFOs. The government was lying to you, his theories went. Aliens were in on it. JFK was killed because he was about to reveal the stuff about the government and the aliens.

In 2001 Cooper shot a sheriff’s deputy who had come to arrest him after a dispute with a neighbor, and Cooper was then shot and killed. But one legacy he left with all of us was his oft-repeated instruction, “Do your own research,” which for years became a catchphrase mostly for the woo-woo set of America — the Elvis-is-alive crowd, the Fox Mulders, QAnon — until this week when Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said it in an interview with Dr. Phil.

annotations.paragraph: The context was vaccines (it’s always vaccines with that guy), and the advice was directed to new parents. “Part of the responsibility of being a parent is to do your own research,” he responded to a woman who asked a question related to vaccine safety. “You research the baby stroller, you research the foods that they’re getting, and you need to research the medicines that they’re taking as well.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on RFK Jr.'s stance on vaccines and his advice to parents, which is central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Kennedy has spent recent weeks seemingly trying to sound mainstream when it comes to vaccines. “The most effective way to prevent the spread of measles is the MMR vaccine,” he wrote in a social media post in early April following measles-related deaths. But the Dr. Phil appearance was the mask slipping and the dog whistles blowing, because “do your own research” in modern America apparently only ever means “hey, maybe we should have injected ourselves with Lysol during covid.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on RFK Jr.'s public statements and contrasts them with his appearance on Dr. Phil, contributing to the narrative of the article.

annotations.paragraph: It probably goes without saying, but just in case: Researching a vaccine is substantially more complicated than researching a stroller. You research strollers by typing “best strollers” into Wirecutter and buying whichever one has cupholders. You research a vaccine by getting a PhD in immunology or cellular and molecular biology, acquiring a lab in which you can conduct months or years worth of double-blind clinical trials, publishing your findings in a peer-reviewed academic journal, and then patiently navigating the government and industry regulations that are required to make sure your vaccine is safe and effective.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critical comparison between researching strollers and vaccines, highlighting the complexity of vaccine research, which is relevant to the article's argument.

annotations.paragraph: Unless, of course, what Kennedy meant by “do your own research” was “faff around on the internet until you find someone saying something you like,” in which case, sure. You can probably knock that out in an afternoon.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a sarcastic critique of the phrase 'do your own research,' which is central to the article's argument.

annotations.paragraph: “Do your own research” is an insidious phrase. It’s the brother of “just asking questions,” the cousin of “for argument’s sake.” It sounds objectively neutral. Nobody is saying you should believe their research, just your own — nobody is pushing an agenda. But it is based on an unspoken shared understanding that the official story is suspect. That research by experts is a scam. That there are things that nobody wants you to know. In 2023, University of Wisconsin-Madison and University of Michigan researchers published a study that found that when people felt positively about “doing their own research,” they were more likely to believe misinformation about the pandemic and to mistrust scientific institutions in general.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides analysis and evidence on the implications of the phrase 'do your own research,' supporting the article's main argument.

annotations.paragraph: In the real world, if parents were truly doing quality research, they would be learning and believing that so-called links between vaccines and autism have been repeatedly discredited, and that inoculating your child against deadly diseases is the best way to protect them from deadly diseases. Instead, we’re somehow having measles outbreaks in the year of our Lord 2025. You would think that the HHS secretary might pivot away from the language tics of the conspiracy theorists instead of trotting them out with Dr. Phil, but then again this is the same man who confidently declared that “autism destroys families” and that “many [autistic individuals] will never use a toilet unassisted.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on RFK Jr.'s statements and their implications, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: “Do your own research” is a way of saying that scientific theories are in the eye of the beholder. The problem is not that the phrase is lying about the truth, it’s that the phrase is implying there is no such thing as the truth. There’s only what you can find online and what I can find online, and how you can build those tidbits into a house and I can build them into a flaming port-a-potty.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the implications of the phrase 'do your own research,' which is central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: The phrase is designed to destabilize, and it works in partnership with algorithms that are also designed to destabilize — AI, YouTube podcasts, an endless parade of did you know? videos on TikTok where the content is either a fabrication or fully dumb. (No, squirting toothpaste on an egg won’t turn it into a squishy ball.) Start down the wrong rabbit hole and you get less well-informed, more outraged and less empowered, all the while being flattered into believing you’re the one controlling your information diet.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on how the phrase 'do your own research' interacts with modern media, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: “Do your own research” is also a problem because, damned if science isn’t out to get you sometimes. The Tuskegee Syphilis Study was real. The history of women’s health issues being dismissed by doctors is well-documented. Because when my daughter was 2 months old I started to wonder if she had a milk allergy, and her pediatrician was dubious, but I bought the hypoallergenic formula anyway and suddenly the symptoms seemed to go away. “Do your own research” feels like a way of wresting back some control in a world that is often complex and terrifying, even if it turns out that control is an illusion.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on why people might feel compelled to 'do their own research,' which is relevant to the article's discussion.

annotations.paragraph: I wasn’t sure, when I started writing this column, whether my goal was going to be to take a swipe at RFK Jr. — a nepo baby wastrel who is busy promising to Make America Healthy Again while cutting back HHS programs that assist minority and underserved populations — or whether it was going to be to trace the linguistic history of a four-word phrase — a phrase that sounds like a celebration of intellectual exploration and is really an invitation to divorce yourself from reality and then lash out at the people who try to bring you back.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the author's intent and the dual focus of the article, relevant to understanding the piece.

annotations.paragraph: Maybe both? Maybe neither. Maybe this is just a lament for how we got to this place, where parents are confused enough to ask whether they should accept long-standing medical guidelines that one of the top medical figureheads in the country doesn’t seem to know if he accepts, either. As I finished typing this paragraph, news broke that Kennedy has announced plans to transform the way vaccines are tested, ordering placebos that health experts worry could further erode the public’s trust regarding immunization.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses RFK Jr.'s plans to change vaccine testing, which is directly relevant to the headline about the fallacy of 'doing your own research'.

annotations.paragraph: This man isn’t mailing out cassettes from his living room in Arizona. This man is the head of a multibillion-dollar federal agency whose entire purpose is to safeguard the health and well-being of the country. Apparently he’s doing his own research, and the results could be very bad.
annotations.reason: The paragraph highlights RFK Jr.'s position and the potential negative impact of his actions, which is relevant to the article's main premise.
